title: KKA: Improving Vision Anomaly Detection through Anomaly-related Knowledge from Large Language Models
author: Dong Chen (Zhengzhou University), Zhengqing Hu (Zhengzhou University), Peiguang Fan (Zhengzhou University), Yafei Li (Zhengzhou University), Qidong Liu (Zhengzhou University), Xiaoheng Jiang (Zhengzhou University), Mingliang Xu (Zhengzhou University), ..., Yueting Zhuang (Zhejiang University)
relevance_why: This paper employs large language models to enhance visual anomaly detection, which could provide insights into utilizing similar methods in audio anomaly detection by leveraging linguistic knowledge to generate audio anomalies.
background: Unsupervised anomaly detection aims to identify unusual patterns in data without prior knowledge of anomalies, particularly challenging in visual datasets due to their variability.
contribution: This paper introduces Key Knowledge Augmentation (KKA) to enhance anomaly detection by generating realistic anomalies from Large Language Models (LLMs), significantly improving the detector's ability to distinguish between normal and anomalous samples.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing generation-based methods often produce unrealistic anomalies with limited impact on model training.
technical_comparison.novelty: KKA specifically utilizes prior knowledge from LLMs to create meaningful hard anomalies, which are similar to normal samples, thus improving boundary learning.

key_innovation: The method distinguishes between easy and hard anomalies using knowledge from LLMs and iteratively refines their generation process to better suit the detector's needs.
real_world_impact: Enhancing vision anomaly detection has significant applications in various fields, including surveillance and quality control, potentially leading to better real-time anomaly recognition in critical systems.
limitations: The paper does not specifically mention limitations regarding its method; however, the reliance on LLMs may impose deployment challenges on resource-constrained devices.

new_terms.Key Knowledge Augmentation (KKA): **Key Knowledge Augmentation (KKA)** is a novel technique that leverages anomaly-related knowledge from large language models to generate realistic anomalies to improve unsupervised anomaly detection.

open_sourcing: The code for CMG can be found at https://github.com/Anfeather/KKA
